Award.AwardTitle: The Future VR/AR Network -- Towards Virtual Human/Object Teleportation: NSF Workshop on Networked Virtual and Augmented Reality Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The Workshop on Networked Virtual and Augmented Reality (VR/AR) Communications convenes researchers and practitioners to identify key research challenges in the rapidly developing area of networking for assisted-reality technologies. The 2-day event will be held in Crystal City, VA, on April 23-24, 2018, and attendees will include industry participants, government technologists, and academic computer scientists and engineers representing the networks, theory, systems, and applications communities.<br/><br/>The goals of the workshop are to: (1) identify key technical problems for the academic research community to investigate; (2) establish a long-term vision and corresponding research agenda to realize the envisioned future of ubiquitous networked VR/AR applications; (3) increase research community understanding of the requirements for future networks to support these applications, and (4) identify new applications and societal benefits associated with augmented reality applications. Dissemination of workshop findings will be made through the publication of a workshop report.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this workshop and event was to gather a forum of experts and interdisciplinary practitioners to help identify the most promising horizons to explore to address the challenges standing in the way of enabling seamless and ubiquitous networked virtual and augmented reality applications, and contemplate a community agenda that will integrate emerging threads of related work into collaboration. The workshop set up a research agenda and stimulated actual follow-up studies that resulted in funding received from agencies such as the NSF and NIH and from industy sponsors alike. The PI assessed the positive impact of the workshop through interactions with the community researchers who attended the workshop and with other investigators who followed up on its outcomes. The collaboration network and opportunities identified by the workshop towards building a community have continued to broaden over the course of the project due to the research activities motivated by the workshop and follow-up initiatives promoted by the PI and the workshop participants. Further dissemination of this project's activities and outcomes has been carried out at major IEEE/ACM conferences, leading research universities and labs in the country, and in related publications. The workshop also stimulated wide publicity and attention in online media and popular community publications within the ACM and IEEE.
